awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--A Model/Proxy Synthesis of Walker Circulation Trends During the Last Millennium
awd_abstract_narration:
The Pacific Walker circulation alters weather and climate extremes around the world, but its sensitivity to external climate forcings remains unknown.  In particular,  observational estimates of 20th century trends in the Walker circulation provide conflicting results, with some suggesting a strengthening and others a weakening or no trend, complicating the attribution of these trends to any specific forcing. 

Paleoclimate records can improve the detection and attribution of trends by providing longer-term context, but their use has been hindered by the lack of multi-proxy synthesis products and climate model simulations covering the last millennium.  This project aims to create new quantitative reconstructions of multiple Walker circulation metrics using the recently constructed PAGES Iso2k database, and to evaluate the mechanisms for variability and trends in these metrics using the Community Earth System Model Last Millennium Ensemble (LME) and new simulations with its isotope-enabled complement (iLME). The research seeks to apply these new tools to answer one central question: What are the mechanisms underlying Walker circulation variability and trends from the Last Millennium through the 20th century, and what are the relative roles of external forcings and internal variability?

The potential Broader Impacts (B.I.) includes strong science and educational aspects. Climate variability in the tropical Pacific affects societies and ecosystems; understanding long-term variability of the Walker circulation is thus critical for improving projections of the impacts of 21st century climate change.  This scientifically-interdisciplinary research team is composed entirely of early-career researchers, two of whom are female.  The project will support a graduate student and postdoctoral researcher. High school students from underrepresented demographics will be recruited for summer internships and mentoring through a program that targets diversity in STEM. Finally, the project will produce multi-proxy synthesis reconstructions of tropical Pacific climate variability and iLME ensemble members, all of which will be made available as resources to the wider scientific and civil communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to investigate the drivers of variability and trends in the Pacific Walker Circulation (PWC) during the Last Millennium and the 20th/21st centuries. Variations in the PWC impact climate across the globe, but instrumental observations are too short to capture the range of behavior that can occur on timescales beyond a few decades. As a result, the PWC's responses to external climate forcings (such as volcanic eruptions and greenhouse gases) have been difficult to tease apart from the substantial amount of variability that is simply intrinsic to the PWC system.

This project provided a longer-term perspective on the PWC by leveraging signals contained in the stable isotope ratios of modern environmental waters (such as rainfall) as well as in geologic archives. First, we examined the PWC's imprint in the year-to-year variations in modern rainfall isotopes (1982-2015). We utilized a blend of data processing techniques that allowed us to produce reliable estimates of oxygen isotope ratios in precipitation from stations distributed around the world. Using this dataset and climate model simulations, we found that the PWC influences rainfall isotopic composition around the world, even in stations far outside the tropical Pacific. This exciting result meant that the global isotopic fingerprint could be leveraged to reconstruct PWC behavior well beyond the timeframe of the instrumental era. Therefore, we then turned to paleoclimate "proxies" for the isotopic composition of environmental waters, e.g., from corals, glacier and ground ice, speleothems, lake sediments, marine sediments, and tree cellulose. We finalized and released a publicly-available compilation of more than 600 such proxy records, with distributions compatible with three programming languages (Python, R, and MATLAB) and sample code to get users started with the database. We made new updates to the database including incorporation of age uncertainty into each record where raw age control data was available. Using this database, we then performed a series of statistical reconstructions of the PWC since 1200 C.E. The resulting set of PWC reconstructions include as rigorous and comprehensive a treatment of methodological uncertainties as possible -- including 5 statistical methods, 3 different "training" datasets of modern instrumental variables, a rigorous treatment of chronological uncertainty, and comprehensive error quantification. Comparison with climate models has enabled us to contextualize the role of different climate forcings (e.g, volcanic eruptions, greenhouse gases) in driving PWC variations during not just the 20th and 21st centuries, but the past ~800 years combined.

Beyond scientific discoveries, the broader impacts of this award included development, planning, and instruction of a one-day "Intro to Climate Change" summer camp module for Hawaiian high school students. The module included hands-on experiments, a field trip, student reflection activities, and lectures on climate science fundamentals (including the Pacific Walker Circulation) that shape Hawaiian rainfall, wind, and temperature patterns. Participation in science was also broadened at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral level via research supervision, mentoring, and professional development. All data synthesized or generated under this award are freely available to the public.
